and so here's roughly how it works so
the standard in its current form
describes three primary constructs for
for application modeling so we have
components which are things that you can
run
like containers or functions or data
stores or message queues or whatever
there's a concept called traits which
are behavior overlays for individual
components
so this would be something like
attaching an auto set of auto scaling
rules
or ingress routing rules to an
individual component
and then we have a we have a thing
called scopes which are
a way to group components together into
applications so these
this provides a semantically significant
application boundary that you can apply
to to create applications out of
a bunch of components so these these are
the main constructs
used in the model
for uh to describe the topology and
behavior of an application
but they're also the main extension
points
so platforms that implement the standard
can decide what types of components
and traits and scopes that they want to
provide so for example
a cloud provider can surface an sdn up
through the model as a scope
to allow um you know grouping of
of components around a network boundary
and so these these extension points
serve as a way to
to get around this lowest common
denominator problem that you typically
see with standards like this where
not every platform obviously is going to
be able to implement all the same
set of capabilities so
the model allows each platform to
surface its own features and
capabilities but in a way that's
consistent
